title: The Biden-Harris Administration Should Engage Ecuador
description: While Ecuador’s challenges should not be understated, President Lasso’s success in the first 100 days augurs well for the country. The United States ought to engage with the Lasso administration before the opportunity passes.

title: The Evening: Afghan Aid, Taliban Seek Recognition, You Wreck Me and More
description: This edition of CSIS's nightly newsletter covers Afghan Aid, Taliban Seek Recognition, You Wreck Me and More.

title: 3 Years Later: An Analysis of GDPR Enforcement
description: The EU's data privacy and protection law, the GDPR came into force in 2018. GDPR enforcement has intensified over the last three years, including an increasing number of fines imposed on companies.

title: Animal Farm Redux
description: This week, the Scholl Chair outlines how the steel industry has been affected by trade laws and imports.

title: How Does Civil Society Protect World Heritage in a World Facing Growing Authoritarianism?
description: CSIS Americas Senior Associate Cristina Burelli and Stephan Dömpke, founder of the NGO World Heritage Watch analyze the recent UNESCO World Heritage Conference in Fuzhou, China and contextualize the desecration of world heritage sites around the world.

title: Beyond COVAX: The Importance of Public-Private Partnerships for Covid-19 Vaccine Delivery to Developing Countries
description: Public-private partnerships are critical to meeting the demand in developing countries to rapidly scale supply and distribution systems for Covid-19 vaccines in support of existing multilateral efforts such as COVAX.

title: Restoring Momentum to U.S. Foreign Policy in the Wake of Afghanistan
description: CSIS senior adviser Norman T. Roule analyzes the broader implications of the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan and offers recommendations for protecting U.S. credibility and security while rebuilding bipartisanship in U.S. foreign policymaking.

title: Women-Owned Businesses in Afghanistan Are in Jeopardy
description: The Taliban takeover threatens to undercut the tentative economic progress made by women entrepreneurs in Afghanistan.

title: Lebanon’s New Government
description: CSIS's Will Todman answers four timely questions about the formation of Lebanon's new government after a year of stalemate.

title: Engaging China on Climate before COP26
description: A deal on climate between the United States and China might be hard to reach before the UN Climate Change Conference of Parties (COP26) in Glasgow. Yet such a deal is also unnecessary.

title: Oceans of Opportunity: Southeast Asia’s Shared Maritime Challenges
description: CSIS held a three-part virtual conference in June 2021 on the maritime challenges facing Southeast Asian states. This white paper discusses urgent human, ecological, food, and climate security issues in the region’s oceans and steps to address these challenges.

title: When Will the United States Have a Special Envoy for North Korean Human Rights?
description: North Korean human rights is clearly an issue that the administration has specified is a priority. The Senate confirmation process, however, may require a little additional time.
